definitions.sensetop: it is fantastic to do something
definitions.labels: (informal)(informal)(informal)(informal)(informal)(informal)(British English, informal)(informal, especially North American English)(informal)

examples.text: This was a **fantastic opportunity** for students.
It was fantastic to see so many families enjoying themselves.
examples.contextForm: it is fantastic to do something

examples.text: The sense of freedom was absolutely fantastic.
We had a really fantastic holiday.
We had really fantastic weather in Rio.

definitions.definition: very large; larger than you expected

examples.text: The response to our appeal was fantastic.
The car costs a fantastic amount of money.

definitions.definition: strange and showing a lot of imagination

examples.text: fantastic dreams of forests and jungles

definitions.definition: impossible to put into practice; impossible to believe

examples.text: It may sound rather fantastic, but it's the truth.
The plot gets increasingly fantastic as the film goes on.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘unreal’): from Old French fantastique, via medieval Latin from Greek phantastikos, from phantazein ‘make visible’, phantazesthai ‘have visions, imagine’, from phantos ‘visible’ (related to phainein ‘to show’). From the 16th to the 19th cents the Latinized spelling phantastic was also used.
